list.title: Question 1
list.content: Consider the function $f(x)=\dfrac{3x+4}{2x+k}$. - Write down the domain of $f$ in terms of $k$. [1] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$ in terms of $k$. [2] - Hence write down the value of $k$ such that $f(x)$ is a self-inverse function.[1]

list.title: Question 2
list.content:
The function $f$ is of the form $f(x) = \dfrac{ax+b}{2x+c}$, for
$x \neq -\dfrac{c}{2}$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$.
Given
that the graph of $y = f(x)$ has asymptotes $x = -5$ and $y = 2$, and
that the point
P$\left(1,-\dfrac{1}{12}\right)$ lies on the graph, find the values of
$a, b$ and $c$.
list.markScheme:
Using the vertical asymptote $x = -5$, we get

$$
\begin{aligned}
\text{[denominator of $f$ at $-5$]} &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
2(-5) + c &= 0 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5em} \answer{c = 10}
$$

Using the horizontal asymptote $y = 2$, we find

$$
\begin{aligned}
\hspace{0.1em} \lim_{x\rightarrow\pm\infty} f(x) &= 2 \\[6pt]
\dfrac{a}{2} &= 2 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{4.4em} \answer{a = 4}
$$

Using the coordinates of the point P, we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
f(1) &= -\dfrac{1}{12} \\[6pt]
\hspace{3.4em} \dfrac{4+b}{2+10} &= -\dfrac{1}{12} \\[10pt]
4+b &= -1 \\
\end{aligned}
$$


$$
\hspace{5.2em} \answer{b = -5}
$$

list.title: Question 3
list.content: Consider the function $\displaystyle f(x)=b+\frac{4}{x+a}$, $\hspace{1em}$ where $a,b \in \mathbb{Z}$. The equation of the vertical asymptote of $f(x)$ is $x=2$ and $f(\tfrac{2}{3})=0$. - Write down the value of $a$.[1] - Hence, find the value of $b$. [3] - Hence, write down the equation of the horizontal asymptote.[1]

list.title: Question 4
list.content: A rational function is defined by $f(x) = a + \dfrac{b}{x-c}$, for $x \neq c$, where $a,b,c \in \mathbb{Z}$. The following diagram represents the graph of $y = f(x)$. ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/2e4669a2-bbd0-4789-8b97-237e21ae7852/images/57e3eb0c-9ca8-404f-a8a8-d44ee564af63/174d0bc6234e556e44492ded9dca1f7d93a7be93.svg) Using the information on the graph, - state the value of $a$ and the value of $c$ ; [2] - find the value of $b$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{a = -4}$  and
$\answer{c = 4}$
- The point P lies on the graph of $y = f(x)$.
Hence, using the coordinates of P, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2.5em} 0 &= f(6) \\[6pt]
  0 &= -4 + \dfrac{b}{6-4} \\[2pt]
  4 &= \dfrac{b}{2} \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = 8} \hspace{1.9em}
  $$

list.title: Question 5
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{2}{x-a} + b$, for $x \neq a$. The line $x = 1$ is a vertical asymptote of the graph of $y = f(x)$. - Write down the value of $a$. [1] The graph of $y = f(x)$ passes through the point P$(0,3)$. - Find the value of $b$. [3] - Find $\displaystyle \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- $\answer{a=1}$
- Using the coordinates of P, we find

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  f(0) &= 3 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
  \dfrac{2}{0-1} + b &= 3 \\[6pt]
  -2+b &= 3 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{b = 5} \hspace{0.3em}
  $$

- We have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{3em} \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty} f(x) &= \lim_{x \rightarrow \infty}\left[\dfrac{2}{x-1} + 5\right] \\[6pt]
  &= 0 + 5 \\[12pt]
  &\answer{= 5}\end{aligned}
  $$

list.title: Question 6
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5}$, for $x\neq\dfrac{5}{2}$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2] - Find $f^{-1}(x)$. [3] The graphs of $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ have two points of intersection. - Find the coordinates of the two points of intersection. Give your answers to two decimal places. [3] - Hence find the equation of the perpendicular bisector to the two points of intersection. [3]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x+4 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= -\dfrac{4}{3}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept are $\answer{\left(-\dfrac{4}{3},0\right)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)+4}{2(0)-5} \\[6pt]
    &= -\dfrac{4}{5}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept are $\answer{\left(0,-\dfrac{4}{5}\right)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{2} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal asymptote is $\answer{y = \dfrac{3}{2}}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{align*}
    [\text{denominator of $f$}] &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    2x-5 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= \dfrac{5}{2}
    \end{align*}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical asymptote is $\answer{x = \dfrac{5}{2}}$

- If we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/61d6ea19-c9b6-4e43-b863-25670815218d/aa1013a.PNG)


- We have

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y &= \dfrac{3x+4}{2x-5} \hspace{5.5em} \left[\text{where } y = f(x)\right]
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Therefore

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  x &= \dfrac{3y+4}{2y-5} \hspace{3em} \left[\text{where } y = f^{-1}(x)\right] \\[8pt]
  x(2y-5) &= 3y+4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 5x &= 3y +4 \\[8pt]
  2xy - 3y &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y(2x - 3) &= 5x + 4 \\[8pt]
  y &= \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3} \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-3em}\tcbhighmath{f^{-1}(x) = \dfrac{5x+4}{2x-3}}
  \end{align*}
  $$

- Sketching $f(x)$ and $f^{-1}(x)$ on the same axes, we can find the points of intersection using the G.D.C.
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/9bb89137-6a40-482f-8a89-a20425dad3b5/images/897ceffb-d901-4e38-a2bb-f444d24cc122/aa1013b.PNG)


- The midpoint of AB is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  \left(\dfrac{x_1+x_2}{2} , \dfrac{y_1+y_2}{2}\right) &= \left(\dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2} , \dfrac{-0.45+4.45}{2}\right) \\[8pt]
  &= (2,2)
  \end{align*}
  $$

  Point A and point B both lie on the line $y=x$, which has gradient $m=1$. Therefore the perpendicular bisector has gradient $m=-1$.
  The equation of the perpendicular bisector is given by

  $$
  \begin{align*}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[8pt]
  y - 2 &= -(x - 2) \\[8pt]
  &\hspace{-0.525em}\tcbhighmath{y = -x + 4}
  \end{align*}
  $$

list.title: Question 7
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1}$, for $x\neq-1$. - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the coordinates of: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept. [3] - For the graph of $y = f(x)$, find the equation of: - the horizontal asymptote; - the vertical asymptote. [3] - Hence sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Solving the equation $f(x) = 0$ for $x$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \dfrac{3x-6}{x+1} &= 0 \hspace{2em} \\[6pt]
    3x-6 &= 0 \\[10pt]
    x &= 2\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $x$-intercept
are  $\answer{(2,0)}$
  - Evaluating $y = f(x)$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \hspace{4.8em} y &= f(0) \\[6pt]
    &= \dfrac{3(0)-6}{0+1} \\[6pt]
    &= -6\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the coordinates of the $y$-intercept
are  $\answer{(0,-6)}$

- 
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    \lim_{x \rightarrow \pm \infty} f(x) &= \dfrac{3}{1} \hspace{2.5em} \\[6pt]
    &= 3\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the horizontal
asymptote is
$\answer{y = 3}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{6em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Hence, if we sketch the graph of $y = f(x)$, we have
  ![SkillUpp Image](https://assets.revisionvillage.com/public/question/afc5956d-9845-488e-810c-bb260e443e8e/images/da49f8cb-1329-4f71-ab39-25e1b4760c7c/5aa8339f9ee09bb9f920e735960c8b3bddfc8e2c.svg)

list.title: Question 8
list.content: Let $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$, for $x \neq -1$. - For the graph of $f$, find: - the $x$-intercept; - the $y$-intercept; - the equation of the vertical asymptote. [5] Let $g(x) = x-3$, for $x \in \mathbb{R}$. The graphs of $f$ and $g$ intersect at points A and B. - Find the coordinates of A and B. [5] - Find the equation of the straight line that passes through A and B, giving your answer in the form $y = mx + c$. [3] - Write down the gradient of the line that is perpendicular to the line passing through A and B. [2]
list.markScheme:
- 
  - Since the equation $f(x) = 0$ has no solutions, there are
$\answer{\text{no \(x\)-intercepts}}$
  - Evaluating $f(x) = \dfrac{5}{x+1}$ for $x = 0$, we have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    f(0) &= \dfrac{5}{0+1} \hspace{3.6em} \\[6pt]
    &= 5\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the $y$-intercept is
$\answer{\mathrm{P}(0,5)}$
  - We have

    $$
    \begin{aligned}
    &= 0 \hspace{4em} \\[6pt]
    x+1 &= 0 \\[6pt]
    x &= -1\end{aligned}
    $$

    Hence the equation of the vertical
asymptote is
$\answer{x = -1}$

- Solving the equation $f(x) = g(x)$ for $x$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  \hspace{2em} \dfrac{5}{x+1} &= x-3 \\[6pt]
  5 &= (x+1)(x-3) \\[9pt]
  5 &= x^2 - 2x - 3 \\[9pt]
  0 &= x^2 - 2x - 8 \\[10pt]
  0 &= (x+2)(x-4) \\[10pt]
  x &= -2,\hspace{0.25em}4 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$

  Evaluating $g(x) = x-3$
for $x = -2$ and $x = 4$, we find

  $$
  \hspace{3.1em} \begin{array}{rcccl}
  y &=& g(-2) &=& -5 \\[9pt]
  y &=& g(4) &=& 1
  \end{array}
  $$

  Hence we find
$\answer{\mathrm{A}(-2,-5)}$
and
$\answer{\mathrm{B}(4,1)}$
- Using the gradient formula with A$(-2,-5)$ and B$(4,1)$, we have

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  m_{\mathrm{AB}} &= \dfrac{y_2 - y_1}{x_2 - x_1} \\[6pt]
  &= \dfrac{1-(-5)}{4-(-2)} \\[10pt]
  &= 1\end{aligned}
  $$

  Hence, using the point-gradient formula with
A$(-2,-5)$ and $m = 1$, we get

  $$
  \begin{aligned}
  y - y_1 &= m(x - x_1) \\[6pt]
  \hspace{0.15em} y - (-5) &= (1)(x-(-2)) \\[6pt]
  y + 5 &= x + 2 \\
  \end{aligned}
  $$


  $$
  \answer{y = x-3} \hspace{0.15em}
  $$

- $\answer{m_{\perp\mathrm{AB}} = -1}$
